text:
Hello. I'm having a problem running a simple filtering function over a Dict. It seemed to work on Julia 1.4 but is giving me errors in Julia 1.5.3
Here my problem, I have a Dict `d` with initialized Int64 zeros looking like this:
`Dict{Any,Int64}("A33:01" => 0,"A23:01" => 0,"B15:01" => 0,"B39:01" => 0, ... )`
The filtering function is something like:
`filter((k, v) -> v >= 4, d)`
I'm using that form according to this guide <https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Introducing_Julia/Dictionaries_and_sets>
In this case I would expect an empty set, but I'm getting the following  error:
`MethodError: no method matching (::var"#887#890"{Int64})(::Pair{Any,Int64})`

It seems a trivial type-related issue, but I'm not sure why it's happening in 1.5.3 since it used to work on Julia 1.4.
Any ideas about what's going on here?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

I think there was a question which was exactly this a couple of days ago. The solution was to change the filter predicate signature to
 `((k, v),) -> v >= 4`

attachments.fallback:
[February 9th, 2021 1:00 PM] tchr: Why is that
```d = Dict("a"=>1, "b"=>2, "c"=>3)
filter!(d) do (k, v)
    iseven(v)
end```
is happy, but
```d = Dict("a"=>1, "b"=>2, "c"=>3)
filter!((k,v) -> iseven(v), d)```
is sad and throws `ERROR: MethodError: no method matching (::var"#114#115")(::Pair{String,Int64})`? How am I doing this wrong?
attachments.text:
Why is that
```d = Dict("a"=>1, "b"=>2, "c"=>3)
filter!(d) do (k, v)
    iseven(v)
end```
is happy, but
```d = Dict("a"=>1, "b"=>2, "c"=>3)
filter!((k,v) -> iseven(v), d)```
is sad and throws `ERROR: MethodError: no method matching (::var"#114#115")(::Pair{String,Int64})`? How am I doing this wrong?

text: > `filter` gives you a single pair that you need to destruct, so you need to create a function that takes a single argument

elements.text: gives you a single pair that you need to destruct, so you need to create a function that takes a single argument

text: i.e. `(k, v) -> ...` is a 2-placed function while `(pair) -> ...` is 1-placed, and you need to subsequently do the destructuring `(k, v)` <- `pair` .

elements.text: is 1-placed, and you need to subsequently do the destructuring

text:
Great! Thanks for the prompt explanation!

filter(((k, v),) -> v >= 4, d)  actually works :grinning:!
